result.rationale: This species is distributed in seasonal wetlands of Lower Parana and  Lower Uruguay ecoregions, and Atlantic coastal basins in Argentina. The area of occupancy (AOO) is 36 km<sup>2</sup>. Threats not only in close proximity to the habitat, but also those that are present in the same hydrological basin (especially those upstream), were considered and include forestation and desiccation of wetlands to prevent flooding and to gain area for soy and rice crops. There are three locations, and continuing declines in extent of occurrence (EOO), AOO and habitat based on these threats. As a result, this species is listed as Endangered.
result.geographicrange:
This species is distributed in Argentina and Uruguay in seasonal wetlands of Lower Parana and Lower Uruguay ecoregions, and Atlantic coastal basins.

Distributional data on this species are very detailed, based on intensive and extensive field sampling (from 1998-2015), and a bibliographical revision (Alonso et al. 2016).
result.population: There is no information on the population trend.
result.habitat: The habitat for Austrolebias elongatus, as in other annual fishes of the genus, is flatland seasonal ponds that remain dry on average for four months (from late spring to autumn, in the southern hemisphere). Dry conditions are necessary for successful embryo development and viability (Berois et al. 2014). Soils with high percentage of clay seem to be the best for egg deposition. The minimum wet period for individuals to reach maturity and reproduce is around two months; reproduction is continuous from adulthood to death (Berois et al. 2014). Ponds may be filled by rains or adjacent stream floods. Adults are found in a wide range of water temperatures from 6°C to 24°C, but higher temperatures could reduce survival. Austrolebias species feeds on aquatic and terrestrial invertebrates (microcrustaceans, oligochaetes, insect larvae, arachnids, etc.) (Laufer et al. 2009). Potential predators are larger fish species, insect larvae, aquatic snakes and birds.
result.threats:
Threats for Austrolebias elongatus are: 
  1. Annual & perennial non-timber crops. The distribution of this species is in areas used for soy crops.  
  2. Fishing & harvesting aquatic resources. Annual fishes are very popular in the pet trade, and national regulations of collecting activities are not tight.  
  3. Nutrient loads. Soy crops use high quantities of fertilisers that may cause eutrophication in seasonal ponds. 
  4. Herbicides and pesticides. Soy crops use high quantities of these substances that may reduce subpopulation viability (Zebral et al. 2018)
  5. Urbanization. This desiccates seasonal wetlands. 
  6. Droughts. Considering global climate change predictions, severe droughts for more than two consecutive years may eliminate subpopulations of annual fishes.   
  7. Storms & flooding. Annual fish embryos need a brief period (time unknown) of drought to normally complete their development. Floods in spring and summer may negatively affect embryos viability.
result.conservationmeasures:
Conservation actions recommended are:
  1. Improve national legislation and infrastructure to control harvesting (fishing).
  2. Create protected areas considering the distribution of all subpopulations of this species. 
  3. Create and promote safe agricultural practices that avoid desiccation, eutrophication and pollution of seasonal ponds and wetlands.
Wetlands in Uruguay are supposedly protected by law, but this is not always implemented. All Austrolebias species are considered priorities for the National Protected Areas System, but few species (or few localities) are protected within such areas.
result.usetrade: This species is used as a pet. Austrolebias species are subject of research in developmental biology, ecology, and evolution (Berois et al. 2015).
